title.narrative: OUTPUT 1.1: HEALTH & NUTRITION SYSTEMS STRENGTHENING

description.narrative: National health and nutrition\202Fpolicies and strategies are developed based on quality data, which contributes to Health And Development In Early Childhood And Adolescence, Health Systems Strengthening, Immunization Services As Part Of Primary Health Care, Nutrition In Early Childhood, Nutrition â€“ General, Strengthening Primary Health Care And High-Impact Health Interventions. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Data, Research, Evaluation And Knowledge Management, Evaluations, Research And Data, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building, Systems Strengthening To Leave No One Behind. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: Children and women benefit from quality health and nutrition services with a focus on the most vulnerable groups

sector.narrative: Child health policy advocacy, evidence generation, national / subnational capacity development

Implementation of community based integrated prevention and management of childhood illnesses (e.g. iCCM)
Strengthening data and national information systems, including routine systems, nutrition surveys and assessments (early childhood nutrition)

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: National health and nutrition202Fpolicies and strategies are developed based on quality data

description.narrative: To strengthen evidence-based planning, UNICEF evaluated its IYCF programme and supported MOH to implement a field study on iodine deficiency among school children. Two studies supported the roll out of COVID-19 vaccinations: A study on the cold chain system and two rounds of a demand generation assessment. An on-going study on the costing of primary health care will feed into the future planning for the health care system in the country. Finally, UNICEF, WHO and UNFPA supported MOH to finalize its Maternal, Child, and Adolescent Health Strategy, which will be published during the first quarter of 2022. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:14/01/2022
